The move is a good idea. The entire area of the code should be marked `@Experimental` and/or `@Internal` - it seems pretty good. But I think users will quickly start relying on the core, so it is potentially disastrous to have the wrong API here.
I believe we should limit the PR to getting stuff out of the core SDK and essentially not address anything that might be improved in the runner-only bits.

Failure in Apache Beam :: SDKs :: Java :: IO :: Hadoop, retest this please.

> As more and more exclusive features are brought up, I'm thinking it's time to create dedicated KafkaIO for each version. @rangadi any thoughts?

It is more of new features in recent versions of Kafka. I don't think we need to separate versions of KafkaIO (and all the maintenance and customer confusion it brings) yet. The current approach is fine as long as we make it clear to the users with good log messages. E.g. if a user sets start time with 0.9 client in classpath, the failure message should clearly say it only supported in newer versions of Kafka client, and point them to a link that describe how to use different versions of Kafka consumers with Beam. This is not done in this PR, but we should.
Even for an internal package, I don't know that making all empty is correct.
Precommit is now pushing 100 minutes, so it timed out after finishing Python but before finishing aggregated javadoc.

We've seen some streaming pipelines run and terminate correctly, so I'm optimistic about the config. It will blow our timeout on ValidatesRunner, since we already had to bump it from 100 to 120 just to finish the batch tests.

We've got good stuff in the works to make this work with Jenkins pipelining/parallel execution so until then we might find a way to make it easy to execute like this via unskipping something, but not built into the postcommit.
LGTM

What would you recommend? empty __all__ will prevent import * and better than adding an internal only comment in that sense.

We could just leave the internal only comment in the __init__.py and revert other changes.

R: @lukecwik
Run Java PostCommit

+1 to not separate versions of KafkaIO. I have used Flink's kafka connectors. That is too complicated and not friendly to developers and users.
Perhaps there is not so much exclusive features. The most important feature is to support the timestamp.

two questions about class `AggregationCombineFn`

1. Is it possible to utilize the existing `Count`, `Sum` CombineFns in Beam rather than implementing them ourselves?
    *  I `feel` there might be some difficulties, just not clear `why`
2. Does it make sense to extract the actual aggregation logic of `Count`, `Sum` etc out of  `AggregationCombineFn`, let `AggregationCombineFn` be a wrapper class, which wraps several aggregation functions together? It makes introducing new aggregation functions(UDAF) easier.

Thank you for reviewing. The use cases:
1. Kafka brokers retain messages for some period of time (e.g. 7 days). If user develop a pipeline to count user visitor per day. He just want the messages of today when run the pipeline. The old messages are just used by other pipelines or data comparison sometimes. 
2. Sometimes users will greatly modify their pipelines, which will cause the pipeline to can not reuse the state and CheckpointMark. So the user want find a suitable point in time to start running again. In the above case, the user will restart from 24 o'clock. This is very common in our production. This is a bit related to https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/BEAM-1775

About https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/BEAM-2185 . We just add start read time here.
R: @robertwb

Sounds good. I think this is a good start. Bounded source support can be added later.
Please address the comments above and couple more things : 
  - Good JavaDoc for 'withStartReadTime()' explaining when it takes effect and overrides consumer config (`auto.offset.reset` is not used and any committed offsets are not used either). 
  - Initialization should fail descriptive message if Kafka version is too old.
  
> If no message has a timestamp that is greater than or equals to the target time, a null will be returned. In this case, we need read the latest.

Makes sense. It would better to log this since it is quite unusual. May be it could even be an error.

> If the message format version in a partition is before 0.10.0, i.e. the messages do not have timestamps, null will be returned for that partition. In this case, we need read the latest too, because these messages are invalid.

Shouldn't this be a failure? I don't think reading from latest is correct. If we can't distinguish between 'no messages later than T' and 'this partition does not support timestamp based offset', I think it would be better to fail.

* I don't want to necessarily apply this to other streaming runners, as I'm not 100% whether it's necessary there. I would prefer experts in those runner decide whether this makes sense, and apply this to those runner if necessary.
* tgroh already addressed this. We are already inside PipelineRunner here.
